review_title: Good Company Facing Market and Management Headwinds
pros: Great pay, great benefits, good work life balance. The company treats its employees well. Good challenging problems to work on.
cons:
Many decisions at the executive and board level over the past 5-7 years have diluted the company's focus. Oil refining is what originally made the company great but it has heavily invested in other ventures. It's questionable whether these fit with and support the company's core competencies. If you've read Good to Great and specifically about the "doom loop", that mentality seems to pervade a lot of the culture and decision-making.

It also doesn't help that regulatory and market conditions have made oil refining an increasingly difficult industry to operate in. The company is adapting the best it can, but some of the conditions have reinforced the negative mentality towards oil refining at the executive and Board of Directors level.
Advice to Management
Remember that oil refining is what originally made the company great. Stick to the basics and, if you believe in your core business, invest heavily in it rather than anywhere else.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Remember that oil refining is what originally made the company great. Stick to the basics and, if you believe in your core business, invest heavily in it rather than anywhere else.
Helpfu

review_title: Has become an awful, awful place to work
pros: Pay and benefits were competitive.
cons:
After years of stability with a stable leadership team, upper management decided to make changes at the top of IT, and it has become a huge mess. Really good SAP resources are leaving in droves or have already left. IT Infrastructure is next. Was a great place to work for years, and now has become a toxic environment. And they are looking at heavy, heavy outsourcing arrangements of IT support, and that never turns out well.

Accounting has been a mess for a decade as well. HFC is likely to be acquired at some point soon anyway, so long term outlook for employees (at corporate at least) is bleak.
Advice to Management
None. It is beyond hope.

review_title: Short-term outlook for rewards of pay and benefits is good; long-term outlook for rewards is up in the air
pros: Good pay and great benefits
cons:
A portion of company leadership is knowledgeable about their specific areas of responsibility, but lack skills required to successfully lead the organization. There is a lot of talk about collaboration, but the reality is that focus and efforts are confined to each department, with little thought given to the overall impact on the organization. Many people looking after their individual interests and taking shortcuts on projects in order to check the box and build their resume.
Advice to Management
Lead by example, delegate responsibilities and hold yourself, and others, accountable for walking the talk and meeting performance objectives. Accept that being a SME does not automatically translate into being a great leader and that you have to first acknowledge an area of weakness before you can work to strengthen it. Weaknesses have the potential to become strengths, but can easily become liabilities if they are never acknowledged or addressed.

pros: Every other Friday off! Excellent location, Parking garage plays classical music. Microscopic stress levels. Vendors will perform all critical tasks for you, Great career if you can drink the vapid kool-aid.
cons:
The IT culture is one that purchases software due to a lack of technical understanding. There are no Open Souce products in the company, like Bind9. The System Architect role is a glorified GUI admin, no understanding of the command line or serious automation. However, this is understandable as there is only about 1500 knowledge works other skilled workers have a small need for local IT services. There is also little understanding of the basics like DNS, DHCP, and the OSI layers. For example, the company just recently just migrated Active Directory over from .com to .local. Infrastructure software and hardware is dated with everything the salesman needed to unload or do to a lack of This company is 99,99% Microsoft shop. There is no tolerance to open source products.
Advice to Management
I would suggest looking for work at Manging a Burger King or McDonald's, technology is not your thing.
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: I would suggest looking for work at Manging a Burger King or McDonald's, technology is not your thing.

pros: Decent pay when they are not trying to screw you out of overtime or holiday pay.
cons:
The control center is highly sexist as there is not a single female controller working within, and on a monthly basis one of their long time employees loves to have very unprofessional/harassing conversations with the other employees. If you are part of the "club" you can make as many mistakes as you want and never get fired, however if you are not part of the club you will be crucified after one or two mistakes. Management was virtually non-existent, when they were around micro managing was non-stop, all fellow employees are only looking to cover their own instead of working together as a team and will not hesitate to throw one another "under the bus".
Advice to Management
Get someone in to manage the control center that actually cares about the employees and listens to what the controllers have to say about the software problems/includes them in the decision making process on what they think needs to be done. Pay the industry average, stop being so cheap this is an oil company.

Helpfu

pros: Can quickly gain a lot of experience, as at any refinery. There are some good people who a good to work with and top level management has a good strategy and good stated values.
cons:
The culture at the upper levels is vastly different than the real culture among operators, maintenance and front line engineers. Middle management becomes a wall between what the company says its values and priorities are and what they really are. They also react very poorly to suggestions for safety or improvement from front line workers. The entire middle management team in Cheyenne is ex-military with very little or no refinery experience which causes them to be easily threatened by any suggestions regarding safety or best practices. It also leads them to make some very risky calls without every realizing it. Cheyenne has a very poor safety record and very high risk tolerance (far higher than should be acceptable in this industry) - the only thing between this refinery and a major incident or death is luck. As stated in other comments, crude and racist comments are common both among front line workers and middle management. 

Other refineries in the company seem better, but stay away from Cheyenne!!!
Advice to Management
Hire managers with experience who can lead this refinery into a stronger safety culture and prevent a major accident.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Hire managers with experience who can lead this refinery into a stronger safety culture and prevent a major accident.

pros: Pay, job stability due to the nature of the industry,benefits, work with nice ppl. Good bonuses. Clean office.
cons:
Overworked, you are an "hourly" employee but you cant collect overtime when it is worked, culture is very serious- no joking around its a rather miserable enviornment. Old school approach to things, overly "professional". I wouldnt recommend to a friend because I wouldnt want them to be as stressed out as I was. Very demanding job, cant take a lunch break because it will put you behind and you wont be able to leave on time.
Advice to Management
Smile-tell a joke you only live once. Give praise to employees, under staffed. Let employees leave an hour or two early if they have a dr app- dont make them use a vacation day... Coordinate out of work outings to boost morale, be appreciative just because you put in 50 hour weeks doesnt mean others should...

review_title: Great Company - WIP culture and leadership
pros: Growing Company, lots of changes and acquisitions. Headquarters culture sounds promising. Great Compensation and Benefits
cons:
Headquarters culture sounds promising but way's away to be lived at all divisions.
Old school management styles and old boys club practices still prevail over career advancement opportunities.
As you go up the corporate ladder the number of females decreases to 1 at top leadership positions.
External candidates favored over promoting internal talent making it difficult to move up within the company.
Advice to Management
Walk the talk, value your people and promote a culture of inclusion and growth for your own incredibly dedicated talent. The grass is greener where you water it, Invest in your people first and promote a culture of growth for your own.
Helpfu
